pros: I joined UC a couple of years ago, I was working on my Master's Degree already, and once hired I received tuition remission, providing massive financial savings. They are the most supportive organization that I have ever worked for, they truly value their employees, and strive to make a positive impact in the community. There are so many other opportunities that support skill and career development. It has been a wonderful experience so far!
cons: They tend to pay a little lower than you will find elsewhere, but this is offset by the benefits they offer. It is a large organization with a lot of bureaucracy. Because of the funding they receive they are held to a higher standard than many other organizations. Some systems are a bit archaic and change can happen much slower than elsewhere.

pros: UC sincerely cares about their employees well-being. UC believes in hiring from within, thus the chance to explore lots of opportunities around campus. As a mother of five, the tuition remission is a HUGE benefit. review_title: Fine Place to Be a Graduate Student
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Cincinnati, OH
pros: The University of Cincinnati is getting better at communicating with its graduate student population. When I started in 2020, there was little conversation about what students wanted. In the past year, they have opened up lines of communication for the students. Overwhelmingly, students have asked for more access to counselors and mental health programs. They have obliged and provided us with more resources for that, which is greatly appreciated.
cons: There is too much "forcing" of topics for students in the graduate school. Every week there are a large number of emails, seminars, and events geared towards DEI. I do not have a problem with those events or going to those events, but as a young scientist, seminars are an opportunity to learn new skills from exceptional professionals in our field, but we are forced to listen to DEI presentations, week in and week out. It is too much.

review_title: Unequal pay structures and little oversight of unit management
pros: UC is a great institution with fantastic tuition benefits.
cons: Management in my unit was uneven and often abusive. There was no oversight from the larger university. Raises we're given across the entire university on a percentage basis with little room for individualized consideration. Coupled with unit management playing favorites without regard to work performance for promotion and professional development, employees who were not personal favorites were left to stagnate. I worked there for many years without any promotion and an expectation to work many evenings and most weekends. Exacerbating the feeling of unfairness was the fact that every member of the administration were in the top 1% of income earners, which left a bad taste when equally educated employees were struggling to make ends meet.

cons:
Pay is awful. But that's just academia.

Management is terrible. In the 5 years I taught here, I had 3 deans and 4 division leaders. Our department chair was a total disaster, and the best people left as soon as they could.

Everything you've ever heard about the politics in academia are true. The daggers are so sharp because the stakes are so low.

I've had many jobs over a long career, and this is the one that caused me PTSD symptoms.

pros:
Pay is somewhat competitive given the good benefits of tuition remission (free classes for faculty/staff, ~90% off for spouse/children), pension, and health/dental coverage.
Some remote work flexibility depending upon the department.
Great vacation and sick leave along with two weeks off at the end of December.
Beautiful campus.
cons:
Vertical movement is somewhat difficult without advanced degree, will probably have to bounce around between departments if you want to work your way up.
Have to pay for parking, which ends up being around ~$1000/year.

review_title: Heaven for Tenured Faculty, So-so for Professional Staff
pros: In this backward, boring, conservative Midwest city, higher education provides a little refreshing air to breath. This is a place with culture, activities, world class architecture, and smart people. Most people, no matter faculty or staff, are highly educated and understand the importance of diversity, education, caring of humanity and environment, and globalization. This review is particularly from the standpoint of a professional staff. Pros: great fringe benefits on some areas.
cons: For staff, it lacks any development strategy. You are hired, and you are expected to work, and work, and maybe retire before the job is eliminated, or you die. Nobody cares about if you are productive or not, because when there is budget cut, professional staff's salaries and positions are first to go since they are not represented by any collective bargaining power, not like faculty and nurses. Morale among young professionals is very low because senior management doesn't care. Low salary compared to industry. You have to look for yourself. Not an ideal place to work for aspiring young professionals. In the past 10 years, most staff had two or at most three meager salary increase (1-3%) while the benefits are shrinking year by year. Most staff see actual income shrunk year by year. That is the work place of UC for staff in a nutshell.

job_title: Full Time Faculy in Cincinnati, OH
pros:
There's a steady paycheck and benefits. If you get tenure, you can die here -- RIP.

Living in Cincinnati is super super easy and inexpensive.  

The ER is excellent. I injured myself on campus once (UC was not at fault, just accident prone me), and they stitched me up in time for class.
cons:
I've been a professor at 3 other Colleges or Universities. Academia in general is not in great shape all-over, but UC makes my previous jobs (even the one for a for-profit institution) look amazing. 

If I could afford it, I'd go back to my job as a barrista I had in the1990s.

What really gets me is that the hostile work environment, pressure, politics, and cronyism just hurts the students. The students lose when the administration is continuously playing musical chairs, erecting buildings before they have a purpose or even faculty, and ignoring issues of race, gender, and equality. 

The propaganda is thick, as UC proclaims everything with a bright red banner. It's just sad, though, when you walk into a building that has a huge banner reading "ranked 89th best school of education".  Is that really banner worthy? How about spending that banner money on education so UC can climb to 88th...

My nightmare has largely been due to problems in my local unit. Other units are not so dysfunctional. However, it is VERY clear that most of the university is on a downhill slide. 

However, the medical school, hospital, health research, and pharmacy seem to be doing great. The faculty I know who work in those areas seem pretty happy, and the students too. So, not everything is so bad. 

It's in Cincinnati.

review_title: University of Cincinnati, not bad overall.
pros: The benefits are excellent, and the flexibility that is available for balancing work/life is fairly good, though not always supported by management. The pay is a bit better I believe than for similar positions elsewhere, though certainly nothing like working outside academia. The President is doing a fine job setting institutional priorities and trying to steer the ship in the best direction considering the realities of higher education today.
cons: The opportunities for advancement are extremely limited. Many positions are filled before they're posted, though job searches are conducted anyway to fulfill the official obligation to do so. Creativity and innovation are not necessarily recognized, rewarded or encouraged. Many times creativity is stifled by long standing members of the organization simply because "it's the way it's always been done". The organization is proving very slow to adapt to the realities of higher education in the 21st century at an operational level, though I would say that the President is doing a fine job trying to drag us there, despite the kicking an screaming of the majority.

1. The model and culture is not true academic. You work based on your RVU , see a load of patients, and get paid average academic salary.  being a successful academician in this model is not easy. 
2. despite being easy going and friendly on interview day, turns out it is a very closed society club. not terribly supportive of outsiders. If you are born and raised in Cincinnati, or if you have trained at this university , you are more likely going to be supported to achieve higher ranks. Otherwise, the chances are much lower and you must fight harder. This is very obvious when you look at positions in power, rather than entry level. job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Cincinnati, OH
pros: Good benefits: health, dental, vision insurance; retirement fund; summer-free for some professors; some discount in the bookstore and in public bus (go-metro)
cons:
Some departments judge instructors by one specific quantity of the end-of-semester evaluations: the "overall rating as a professor" without regard to other quantities and actual comments. It ends in some instructors offering extra-credit to students to fill up the evaluation and to give them that specific rating. They do it even if the evaluations are anonymous and they do it by asking students for screenshots.

Another con is that the way they react to the State decision to cut the budget based on graduation rates. Some departments just lowered the standards of passing in order to "retain the students" while others build some "remedial" programs to increase back the "students' scores."

pros: After working in the private sector, taking a position with UC restored my work-life balance, which is the number one reason to work at UC. Also, a great benefit is the opportunity for employees and their families to attend the university tuition-free. The work environment is low in stress and provides plenty of opportunity to learn new skills.
cons: Being a government run institution, change does not come quickly and the competence level is not as high as in the private sector, due to salaries lower than the industry standard. In some cases this results in morale problems, especially among employees who have been at UC a long time. The Clifton area is not the safest place in town and cheap and convenient parking is hard to come by.

review_title: Great place to work if you are dual income
pros: There are a lot of WONDERFUL things about working on a university campus. There is a lot of energy. You are able to play a role in students' lives.
cons: There isn't a pay scale in place to ensure that you are compensated for what you actually do. Whatever pay you hire on with is generally where you will stay unless you are able to change departments and your position. If you enjoy your job, that is actually a bad thing because to get a pay increase you HAVE to change departments!

pros: I love teaching and this is a good place to be. The campus is lively and the students are enjoyable. Lots of freedom.
cons: Faculty can be cliquey - especially towards adjuncts like me.  Teaching 3 classes is not nearly enough money to live on, but they won't give you 4 to make you full time.  Sometimes asked to teach three different preps, online, bigger and bigger class sizes.  I wouldn't care if I were being adequately compensated, but I make $75/credit hour more than a grad student, but they get tuition and health insurance - I do not.

review_title: Nice people, nice environment, but horrible administrators
pros: UC is a beautiful campus, even though the administration is filling it up with new buildings! Lot of middle management people are very nice.
cons: Administration has got their priorities mixed up. With their sole purpose of increased profit (or revenue), everything else that makes (& made) UC a great place is slowly (may be quickly) diminishing. Some of the dept. level administrators (i.e.Professors) are also arrogant &/or egotistical, which makes it harder to work with them. The top-level non-academic administrators are even worse. They are lazy & takes ages to get anything done (worse than state workers) and on top of that they delay everything with unnecessary red-tape. I could go on, but, that sums it up. Love the place, but, unless something change, UC is in the wrong path!

pros:
Good pay and hours, coworkers. Very friendly environment. UC is a great place to work! The benefits are incredible. It's fun, lively campus and there is always something going on.
The culture of UC is very engaging and family oriented. The values at UC are demonstrated on a daily basis by both staff and students.The values at UC are demonstrated on a daily basis by both staff and students. Nice place to work.
cons: May be fast paced at times and jobs that may come with jobs so be ready stay focused and consistent teaches you to adapt to were you are. At times tremendous amount of paperwork.   sourronding area. Other than that not much cons.

pros: Great people to work with. good benefits. Depending on college it can be busy. but cycles are short and when new semester begins, it starts all over.  Fast pace.  Summer semester is slower pace and gives opportunity to catch up and do things that time didn't allow during regular semesters.  Good benefits
cons: Don't feel safe walking to your car in, especially in the evening after class.  Crime has increased on campus.  However, the do have a service that will meet you at your location and walk with you or drive you to your car.  They are working on this.  Also, no advancement if you're in the union.

pros: People are great and the university atmosphere is fun and if you like helping students and faculty it can feel very completing.
cons: Deans\management are absolutely disconnected and can not handle employees who tell the truth about situations. They are more worried about photo ops and perception than overall Employee happiness or business success. Sometimes they don't even put the students first which should be all of the staff\faculties # 1 priority.

pros: Exciting university. A top research institute with impressive ambitions and achievements. Largest employer in Cincinnati and a wide variety of colleges and students. Also a beautiful urban campus.
cons: Work is continually heaped upon existing staff as responsibilities increase and departing employees are not replaced. Everyone tells everyone else how to run their jobs. Quantity is more important than quality. Pay is a tad low considering that the university is a public nonprofit funded by the state government. Budget cuts occur annually.  The workload is frantic.

review_title: UC is a cool place to work. Not very innovative. But cool.
pros: People are very friendly. Supervisors don't micromanage you. In certain functions - like admissions - you can make your own schedule. If you love sports, being able to attend games is a plus. People tend to stay for a long time (20+ years) because it can be comfortable; this is a gift and a curse.
cons: Not very innovative with technology or design. It can take a long time for solutions to be approved because it's such a large university system (45,000 + students). The pay is not that great so you better find some purpose in your job to keep you motivated.

review_title: Good place to work, great people, limited room to grow career-wise
pros: I worked at UC as non-faculty staff employee in an IT-related field. The people were wonderful to work with and the work was interesting & challenging during the tenure of my projects. The management was good and generally kept a good relationship with non-faculty staff. The pay was below industry standards for my field, however the employee benefits made up for it (generous vacation time and enrollment in most university courses were free).
cons: There was no room for me to grow in my technical career at UC. There were openings in management and teaching positions, but I was mostly interested in staying in technical development or research.

job_title: Adjunct Assistant Professor in Cincinnati, OH
pros: Excellent faculty and staff.
cons: Adjunct teaching is something you should do because you love it; the pay will barely cover your commuting costs if you're teaching on campus.  Little guidance  for online teaching.  Many of my online students were able to register for my class despite having none of the prerequisites. The department didn't seem to think this was a problem. Directionless leadership at the college level and a lot of turnover at the dean, provost and president levels.  Enrollment is falling so adjunct positions may become more uncertain.  Departments are understaffed and under-resourced.  As with most large public universities, mission and values are espoused but not enacted.

review_title: Good employer, but colleagues are not all friendly.
job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Cincinnati, OH
pros: The HR department is very effective, and the medical insurance is very good for employees. All the functioning department I have worked with are very nice. The department Head was very nice and helpful.
cons: One thing I don't like, and one that affects my decision of leaving the position, is that the colleagues are very detached from each other, especially when you are new. I was a faculty member, and except for two friends I had known long ago and my supervisors, all other faculty members are like "not knowing me all the time". It's like walking, dining and teaching all by yourself: no help, no instruction, no chat.

review_title: UC's mission is great, but the management is too decentralized.
pros: You truly know that you are making a difference. UC has over 40,000 students and pursues very high level research, and it's good to know that you are making a difference.
cons: The management of employees is horrendous. Starting with the onboarding process, while people in human resources are nice, their systems are outdated and it lead to my not getting payed properly until two months after I started. In addition, the pay is terrible, and the chances of getting a raise without a title change are slim to none.

review_title: Great Place to Work Through College
pros: The scheduling is very flexible and the professional staff members are sure to acknowledge that you're a student first and an employee second. They have been adding more and more professional development programs as well. i get the feeling that they genuinely care about the employees well being and that my work is appreciated.
cons: While I have had a positive overall experience working at the LAC, I know of other student employees who have to take second jobs because the university limits the number of hours that students are allowed to work on-campus jobs.

review_title: You don't work for a university for the money, you do it for the students
pros: I really enjoyed working at UC. It's been one of the best jobs I've had. Although it paid under market, there was no pressure to create things that would sell or bring in revenue. Everything we did was for the students, staff and faculty. We had a solid infrastructure that was way ahead of other companies I've worked for as far as Identity Management was concerned.
cons: The IT department tended to pay for things and buy expensive software when the open source version was fine or the commercial version provided no significant advantages. We also had a very difficult disaster recovery once after a power outage that took several months to recover from.

review_title: Research opportunities are good but the administration is a mess.

cons: The administration is borderline incompetent at many levels. There is very little oversight for how faculty manage their laboratories and student employees. It is very easy to be left out in the wind if your PI overlooks some paperwork or is out of town for a week when the paperwork is due.

pros: There are all kinds of benefits for UC employees. There are excellent benefits and programs to ensure employees are happy.  I've been fortunate to have a wonderful supervisor and department to help me grow in my position.
cons: Unfortunately, in my line of work, there's not much advancement in my position, unless I obtain a much higher level of education, which I'm not planning on pursuing in this particular field.

pros: Working at UC has many benefits such as excellent health insurance coverage, tuition remission, and flexible working hours. I recently began taking advantage of the tuition remission program and I wish I started much sooner. Another benefit from working at an academic institution, you're off on snow days!
cons: Because UC is a public institution, there's very little room for career advancement. Pay raises are standardized and regulated. I started in an entry level position and have had a very difficult time moving up. I suggest taking advantage of the tuition remission program and pursue a higher education degree or certification right away (especially if you start at an entry level position).

- Professors may or may not be very involved with the students; it is up to you to make the most of your research

review_title: Being a graduate assistant at UC
pros: One of the things I like about being at UC is the fact that people are very friendly and helpful. I'm from a small town and the people I work with have helped to make the transition smoother.
cons:
Housing for graduate students is very expensive. I wish they had an apartment primarily for grad students. Many of the places I've viewed are deplorable and very poorly maintained.
Safety is also a great concern for me. Ensure that you get as much information as you can about an area before you move there.

review_title: If you want a low salary, no room for advancement, and poor communication this is the place for you.
pros: The benefits for the University of Cincinnati are amazing.  Medical, Dental, and Vision is just OK.  The 401K is the best my dad has ever seen and he works in stock and finance.  You put in 10% and the University matches and then puts in an additional 3.5%, it is truly fantastic.
cons:
Oh downsides where do I start:

I have been working for the University of Cincinnati for over 3 years now and I thought working at a big University where the research is fantastic and they have all of the 'best' staff and faculty, was a good thing...no I was wrong.  Bigger is not better, you get lost in the ocean of people that work here.  And in some positions you are just a number or another Research Associate.  I work with a lady that has a Bachelors and Masters degree yet she has worked here for 10 years and she has never gotten a raise, her title has never been changed to associate her with long standing status at the University.  

If you ever have worked in research you know that you are a slave to your PI, and this University is no different.  You can work 5-7 years on a project and still have to beg your PI to get it published before your research gets 'scooped' and pray that in the next 6-8 months after your paper finally gets published that you have some shot in h*ll that a company or another University just may want you.  

Some words of advice; if you are applying ask people outside of the department that you are applying for to get there true opinion of what they think about the University.  If you never ask you never know what outsiders really think about your boss or soon to be boss.  Please do your research before coming, because once you are in, it is really hard to get out.

job_title: Post Doctoral Fellow in Cincinnati, OH
pros: Great place to work as a post doc. Cincinnati is an up and coming city.  Cost of living is low.  Work life balance is excellent. Benefits are ok
cons: Quality of work depends on the department you work in, and the particular research lab.  The focus at the University seems to be shifting more towards mass-production of undergraduates and away from core research.

pros: Overall the university is a fun place to work. If you have kids getting ready for college the tuition remission is well worth the job
cons: They are systematically getting rid of those of us over 50. I am the 5th person in my department that they are setting up with silly "charges" to terminate my employment.  Two were eliminated when they eliminated the job they had. One was set up with possible legal trouble if she didn't leave.

review_title: UC is a very good employer.
pros: UC is a dynamic workplace with interesting colleagues.  No workday is ever the same.  There are always challenges, but they are good challenges, professional challenges, situations that grow you as a professional.
cons: UC tries to keep salaries low, since that is the biggest annual cost they have.  Health benefits are very expensive.  I guess this is probably true of many employers, especially after the recession.  UC was affected negatively by the recession in 2008, but they have bounced back and are doing ok now.

review_title: Some things good, others not so . . .  recommend if you have kids attending UC.
pros: Great benefits include tuition remission for you and your dependents.  Generous vacation/sick time.  Good and reasonable health insurance.
cons: Salaries below average.  Salary increases not based on performance, same percentage to all, some years no increase.  Lack of uniformity in hiring process.

pros: Collaborative work environment, strong leadership, and great opportunities for independence and autonomy.
cons: Low salaries and not a lot of opportunities for professional development. Budget cuts seem to be placing more value on paying high level leadership than investments in student success and staff/faculty development.

review_title: Biggest academic medical center in Cincinnati,; cutting edge diagnostic and therapeutics at University Hospital
job_title: Research Assistant Professor in Cincinnati, OH
pros:
I work in the College of medicine.  Advantages:
1.  Great junior faculty mentoring program
2.  Well-known center in academic medicine with a great national reputation
3.  Focused on developing meaningful research programs
4.  Good pay and great benefits
cons:
1.  Too much administrative overhead; operations could be made more efficient
2.  University Hospital has to continuously balance between providing unreimbursed care and upgrading labs, so capital request take a while to get approved.

pros: Research environment in the college of medicine is very collegiate, with lots of collaboration and support among labs.
cons: Recently, the MDI (Reading campus) has been losing it's faculty and research labs.  Without a dramatic intervention from the department/university, the whole institute could rapidly loose steam as the research powerhouse that it has been.

job_title: Academic Tutor in Blue Ash, OH
pros: I enjoy working here because it is a small school, where the professors really care.  I work in the mathematics tutoring lab.  This is a free service for students.  I really love my job because I feel like I am making a difference.  Students who may have hated math can become empowered because they have more individualized help.
cons: Sometimes the bureaucracy can be frustrating, but since I work part-time, I am mostly free to do my job without hassle.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Cincinnati, OH
pros: Good connections to medical networks. Good location, accessible via public transportation.
cons: Difficulty communicating: mass emails are divided between students, staff, and faculty, and anyone who overlaps multiple categories isn't always on the proper lists. interactions with individual deans, offices are fine and the people are generally pleasant, but issues went unresolved and anything that required Official Decisions was delayed or endlessly debated. Money is definitely the bottom line.

job_title: Senior Research Coordinator in Cincinnati, OH
pros: Exposure to new learning opportunities, benefits - vacation and sick are great. Training is extensive, on average it can take up to six months for training to be complete.  Always an opportunity to learn something new everyday
cons: Health Insurance currently is awful, UC advertises they are pro-research however they do not support all research.  A lot of walking around campus - can be a pro or a con depending on the weather.

pros: Flexibility is excellent.  The academic environment is superb.  The campus is beautiful.  There are benefits aside from pay, like the ability to take classes in addition to teaching them.

review_title: Solid facilities and research - mediocre administrative support.

pros: Any position at the University has excellent benefits, an outstanding retirement program, and tremendous job stability.  The problem is that it is difficult to get your foot in the door.
cons: As with any large bureaucracy, methods of doing things are very entrenched.  There also tends to be a fair amount of micro-managing in place.

review_title: Good environment, Easy Scheduling, Constant Income

review_title: Difficult to keep up with values
pros: You meet many people and develop positive, long-lasting connections. The residents I've mentored are bright, intelligent students with amazing goals.
cons: There is an unattainable ideal that is held within the department that forces employees to think a certain way. Much of the department is condescending and extremely clique-y. It has been difficult to manage professional relationships with particular members.

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Cincinnati, OH
pros:

Very High tuition fees (~4400/semester).

pros: Good hours, benefits are great, and the atmosphere was very dynamic.  Enjoyed working with a company that supports its community.

review_title: For a school with management classes, UC does anything but support good management practice
pros: Tuition remission and a diverse crowd are about the only pros I can think of working in the department I do.
cons: Working in my department has been the worst job experience I have had or have even heard of.  My direct supervisor has proven to be spineless, incompetent, and capable of lying.  His supervisor is tyrannical, dishonest, can't admit mistakes, and believes that she is the be all, know all of everything every where.  Management constantly tries to "tighten the screws" on the staff, a staff who's work has repeatedly, during state inspections, been giving glowing reviews, and has been noted by a VP that there have never been any complaints made on my department while out in the field.  Manaegment has had several grievances filed on them just in the last few months by a relatively small staff of about 12, and management continues to challenge Unions and university policy to negatively effect working conditions and to try and take away the compensation provide by union contracts.  When problems continued, I was advised to "Look for a new job, if its that bad" by the VP of research instead of being offered a solution.  Management has zero accountability within my department, and no one ranked above shows any signs of concern.  At one point, it was rumored that 3 staff members were going to potentially go on a killing spree and management did nothing to follow this up nor show concern of this notion.  The excuse was that the "rumor" could not be substantiated.  None of the workers were worried, but that is how management handles things, by not handling them and then making up excuses or out right lies to cover themselves.  Another incident, was during a holiday party where the top supervisor in my department said that "they stopped playing a certain game because the foreigners didn't understand"....not a big deal, but with 2 international employees sitting in the room, it seemed rather crass, rude, and discriminatory coming from a supervisor making $123,000 a year and working for a university that boasts diversity and equal oppurtunity.  The list goes on.  Supervisors approve time off work only to take it back because they made a mistake.  Supervisors deny time off and refuse to approve it unless intimate details are provided surrounding the need for time off.  The most the university has done was require that the supervisors go to training, one in which the top supervisor was the trainer.  How on earth can someone who is the cause of the problem, be able to solve the problem.  Tyranny, incompetence, and dusting things under the rug has been the university's solution to handling the intense problems my department has been struggling to right.  The university does not follow the mission statement they put out there.
